Award.AwardTitle: OPUS: A synthetic Systematic and Phylogenetic Study of the Mustard Family (Brassicaceae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The mustard family (Brassicaceae) includes over 3660 species, of which many are important vegetables (cabbage, cauliflower, broccoli, Brussels sprouts, turnip, radish, watercress, arugula) and sources of industrial and vegetable oils (canola) and condiments (table mustard, horseradish, wasabi). One species, thale cress, is the model organism in experimental plant biology. The family is quite complex, and there are very few young scientists with expertise in this important family. This two-year grant will support the synthesis of the extensive taxonomic/evolutionary literature and vastly unpublished, though nearly complete, work the PI assembled during his 45-year research on the family. All findings, regardless to their stage of completion, will be downloadable from the project website at the Missouri Botanical Garden (MBG). The website will also include plant digital images, comprehensive literature, and simplified electronic keys to assist professionals and students with the easy identification of mustards.

The PI will train 28 undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral botanists through four workshops at MBG to enable them to understand the taxonomic complexity of the family. The Project website will be a major resource and will enhance the infrastructure for research and education by covering all aspects of mustards on a worldwide basis. The information will be used by researchers and students in taxonomy, conservation, education, horticulture, and crop sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

NSF OPUS Grant DEB-1252905

 

     All mustards belong to a large, economically and scientifically important plant family called Brassicaceae or Cruciferae. This family includes many crop plants such as vegetables (arugula, broccoli, Brussels sprouts, cabbage, cauliflower, kale, kohlrabi, radish, rape, turnip, watercress), sources of condiments (table mustard, horseradish, wasabi) and vegetable oils (canola), ornamentals (honesty, stock, sweet alyssum, wallflower), and numerous weeds about 130 species of which were introduced to the United States alone. One of those weeds is called “thale cress or mouse-ear cress” (scientific name Arabidopsis thaliana), a small Eurasian weed that became during the past three decades the model organism in experimental biology. Generous funding from the National Science Foundation (NSF) to many labs led in 1990 to the sequencing of the entire genome of this plant, and that opened the doors to advancing the knowledge in basically every field of plant biology, including systematic botany. Indeed, the NSF grant I received in 1992 resolved the mystery of Arabidopsis from being a genus of over 60 species centered in the Himalaya to our findings that it includes only nine species centered in central Europe.

     For the past 51 years, I have been and continue to be fascinated by the complexity and diversity of the mustard family on worldwide basis, and all my colleagues consider me as the ranking world authority of the family. As my career approaches its final years, the support of the NSF to my personal research, and to the numerous colleagues with whom I collaborated, resulted in the publication over 370 scientific papers and books and the naming of more than 1050 species, genera, and tribes in the family. Furthermore, the collaboration with over 140 botanists worldwide led to our current knowledge of every mustard species native to the New World, China, India, the Himalaya, Japan, Southwest Asia, South Africa, and less so on Australia and New Zealand. As a result, the mustard family is the best known taxonomically of any other large family of plants.

     The above-mentioned OPUS grant was awarded to synthesize my career-long experience of mustards and to train as many young botanists working or interested in the family. Many training workshops lasting between one to three days were held in St. Louis, University of California (Berkeley), University of San Marcos (Peru), Sichuan University (China), Darwinion Institution (Argentina), American University of Iraq, University of Edmonton (Canada), and Heidelberg University (Germany). As a result, well over 120 botanists were trained worldwide, and my interactive key to all mustard genera is currently on the website of the last institution (brassibase.cos.uni-heidelberg.de), which is freely accessible to botanists worldwide.

     In order to fully understand mustards worldwide, and the same holds for any plant group, one needs to study the major collections of plants in museums, institutions, and herbaria, and the OPUS grant facilitated my travels not only to the major collections in the United States (e.g., Harvard Univeristy, Smithsonian Institution, New York Botanical Garden, California Academy of Sciences, UC Berkeley herbaria), but also in Europe (London, Kew, Edinburgh, Paris, Stockholm, Madrid, Copenhagen, Berlin, Munich, Vienna, Prague, Kiev, St. Petersburg), Asia (Tokyo, Beijing, Kunming), South America (Quito, Lima, Buenos Aires, Concepcion, Santiago), and South Africa (Cape). We now know the detailed taxonomy of every tribe, genus, and species of the mustard family, and the results are being gradually synthesized into major revisions for publications. Some of these major works have already been submitted for publication, and others are in their final stages. More importantly, the Missouri Botanical Garden, where I am currently employed and which supported me enormously during my 27+ years, is the coordinating center for the World Flora Online. Many worldwide accounts of a number of families are currently available on its website, and treatments of the mustard family are gradually being prepared to be placed online.

     In summary, senior US scientists, who are experts on the taxonomy, evolution, and systematics of any plant or animal group, would never be able to synthesize their life-long expertise and make it freely available for the next generation of biologists without the generous support of the NSF and its OPUS grants. For that and the earlier support, I am profoundly grateful to the NSF for the tremendous advancement we achieved on the systematics, evolution, and taxonomy of the mustard family.
